title-group.article-title: Schooling, Child Labor, and Reserve Army Evidences from India

contrib-group.aff: Narasinha Dutt College, Howrah, West Bengal, India

fn.p: Dipa Mukherjee teaches at the Department of Economics, Narasinha Dutt College, Howrah, West Bengal, India. After completing her Masters from University of Burdwan, she did her PhD from Jawaharlal Nehru University. She has written in Indian Journal of Labour Economics, Indian Journal of Regional Science, Journal of Educational Planning and Administration, Journal of the Asia Pacific Economy, and Asia Pacific Development Journal, apart from contributing to various edited volumes. Her areas of interest are the Informal Sector, Labor Economics, Economics of Education, and Regional Development. [email: medipa@rediffmail.com]

abstract.p: It is accepted that working from an early age causes physical, moral and psychological trauma for the children and loss of childhood. This article contends that apart from working children, those out of school but not working constitute a reserve army of child workers and policies must focus on them as well. Incidence of schooling, work and the reserve army in India has been examined and factors determining such decisions have been identified using a Multinomial Logit Model. Economic condition, Parental education, Social class, and Gender of the child emerge as important determinants. Focused and collaborative policies are necessary to reach goals of universal schooling.
